title: Fifty passengers refuse to board Air Europa plane in Ibiza after 'problem with the brakes'
text:
12
View
comments
Fifty passengers refused to board a flight after the captain allegedly admitted there was a problem with the plane's brakes.
The Air Europa service was scheduled to leave Ibiza for Madrid at 9.40pm local time, but was delayed firstly by airport workers' striking, and then by technical issues.
The captain allegedly told passengers that the plane would only be able to go as far as Palma in Mallorca, as the plane had 'issues with the brake system.'
The Air Europa flight from Ibiza to Madrid was only able to fly as far as Mallorca due to a problem with the brakes (file photo)
One passenger scheduled to fly, Lucas Torrecilla, told La Vanguardia that he refused to fly as he could not 'risk flying with security issues.'
Another person on board, Miguel Angel Garcia Salas, explained that the captain compared the problem to a car with a damaged ABS braking system.

The passengers were told that a collective decision was in the best interests, however despite 50 people refusing to fly on the plane from Ibiza, others claimed they needed to board to make connecting flights.
The Boeing 737-800 eventually flew on to Mallorca where passengers were transported on to Madrid.
MailOnline Travel has contacted Air Europa for comment, and is awaiting a response.
